Great job Tim. Thanks so much for all the time and money you put into this channel and your live streams.  This is what you should do for sure. If you’re going to be at a launch then obviously you should record it but only live commentate. Post your videos afterwards because people like me who enjoy your content (aside from live events) want to watch you no matter what happens with your live stream. Getting to watch the launch again from different angles a few days later is something I look forward too. Getting to listen to you talk about rockets in general is why I subscribed.  I’ve learned a ton from your channel so please don’t worry about your technical difficulties live streaming. 99% of us understand and don’t fault you. We appreciate the effort and honestly want your commentary more than we want live shots anyhow.  I don’t want to be disrespectful to your effort but I feel like most people watch space x stream during launch/landing anyhow. They have the best video feeds. So for me I didn’t care that you live stream cut out because I was watching space x anyhow. I watch you before and after. In a perfect world watching you live commentate with space x video would be the best.

Do you think space x will land all 3 boosters on drone ships in the future? Following a ballistic trajectory similar to the central core would require less fuel than burning back and could allow for a later separation of the boosters increasing falcon heavy's delta V.

The downside is 2 more drone ships and possibly loosing more boosters due to water landings being more difficult.

Tim, some really cool footage here. But, I have to offer some constructive criticism. Pick one thing and do that. While I know some of the issues on your live stream weren't your fault, a couple items were, and were likely due to you being task saturated. So, either do your main video live stream and concentrate on actually providing footage (ie, following the ascent, decent, etc, with the camera so viewers can actually see, and paying attention when someone is blocking the shot) or, get someone to help run the second camera.


I enjoy your pre-launch banter and your informative commentary, but the primary reason I watch launch live streams is to watch the launch. I'm not sure if the launch lock-up was just due to wireless issues, or of you bumped something when you ran around (in front of the camera) but I really wish I had watched the SpaceX stream instead. Even worse was the landing, where the camera was fixed on an empty part of sky, you're hooting and hollaring about how awesome the landing approach was, and then we got to see an empty sky, followed by a flannel shirt. I've bought stuff from your shop to help support you (I'm laid-off so cant patreon) so I really do appreciate your work. I would guess this was just trying to do too much, and will be a one time "oopsie".

hey man, can you explain how you knew there was going to be a boom? Obviously the sonic boom occurs when an object moves through the air faster than sound, creating the sound of shock waves. But, with these boosters coming back to earth, towards you, the waves would be generated in the direction opposite of the boosters' movement. Also, once the boosters decelerate to < speed of sound, no more sonic boom is being produced. Im not sure at what point the boosters were no longer supersonic, but I suspect they were slowed down long before they got close to earth's surface.. but its almost as if the sonic boom was traveling just behind the boosters, such that when the boosters landed the sonic boom (shock waves) arrived just a few seconds later..
